sub_topic: Find the volume form of a given metric.
message_1:
Consider the Riemannian metric on $\mathbb{R}^3$ given by $$g = dx^2+(y^2+z^2)dy^2 + dz^2.$$ 

Find the volume form of $g$ at the point $(1,0,0)$.
message_2:
To find the volume form of the given Riemannian metric, we first need to compute the determinant of the metric tensor $g$. The metric tensor is given by the matrix:

$$
g = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & y^2+z^2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

Now, we compute the determinant of $g$:

$$
\det(g) = 1 \cdot (y^2+z^2) \cdot 1 - 0 - 0 = (y^2+z^2)
$$

The volume form is given by the square root of the determinant of the metric tensor times the standard volume form in $\mathbb{R}^3$, which is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$:

$$
\text{vol}(g) = \sqrt{\det(g)} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = \sqrt{y^2+z^2} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz
$$

Now, we evaluate the volume form at the point $(1,0,0)$:

$$
\text{vol}(g)(1,0,0) = \sqrt{0^2+0^2} \, dx \wedge dy \wedge dz = dx \wedge dy \wedge dz
$$

So, the volume form of $g$ at the point $(1,0,0)$ is $dx \wedge dy \wedge dz$.
